mainContent.text:
2.1 American Born Chinese

        Completion requirements
        



If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 2, you can open it in Google docs. or any word
    processing application. Use the study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too.

The Graphic Novel
Gene Yang's award-winning graphic novel American Born Chinese combines three forms of literature into one incredible reading experience.  He synthesizes three types of media:
Stories 1, 4, 7: "The Monkey King" tales are based on epic myths (ancient Chinese folktales), with a twist.
Stories 2, 5, 8: The "Jin Wang" episodes are set in modern America (San Francisco Bay), from early childhood to geeky adolescence to rebellious teenage drama.  Is Jin Wang actually Gene Yang?
Stories 3, 6, 9: The cringe-worthy TV-inspired "Everybody Ruvs Chin-Kee" is a parody of a 1980s TV sitcom and gross-out comedy (like Sixteen Candles), full of racist stereotypes.  Don't worry, there is a
    method to its madness!   
Yang weaves a tapestry of thought-provoking questions about what it means to be in an unknown environment, whether you are the new kid in school, an immigrant "Fresh off the Boat," or an animal god among human gods in heaven.  At one point, we've
    all felt like a stranger, an alien, an outsider, and a foreigner in our own skin, whether it is in school, on travels, in romantic relationships, in our own family.  
Get ready for one of the best surprise endings in all of storytelling!
Assignment:  
Read "American Born Chinese" by Gene Yang.  Or, download the PDF version here.


Watch the following videos before you read the graphic novel:




Reading:

2.1 American Born Chinese

Completion requirements

If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 2, you can open it in Google docs. or any word processing application. Use the study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too.

The Graphic Novel

Gene Yang's award-winning graphic novel American Born Chinese combines three forms of literature into one incredible reading experience.  He synthesizes three types of media:

Stories 1, 4, 7: "The Monkey King" tales are based on epic myths (ancient Chinese folktales), with a twist.

Stories 2, 5, 8: The "Jin Wang" episodes are set in modern America (San Francisco Bay), from early childhood to geeky adolescence to rebellious teenage drama.  Is Jin Wang actually Gene Yang?

Stories 3, 6, 9: The cringe-worthy TV-inspired "Everybody Ruvs Chin-Kee" is a parody of a 1980s TV sitcom and gross-out comedy (like Sixteen Candles), full of racist stereotypes.  Don't worry, there is a method to its madness!   

Yang weaves a tapestry of thought-provoking questions about what it means to be in an unknown environment, whether you are the new kid in school, an immigrant "Fresh off the Boat," or an animal god among human gods in heaven.  At one point, we've all felt like a stranger, an alien, an outsider, and a foreigner in our own skin, whether it is in school, on travels, in romantic relationships, in our own family.  

Get ready for one of the best surprise endings in all of storytelling!

Assignment:  

Read "American Born Chinese" by Gene Yang.  Or, download the PDF version here.
